_header: O mortal man mazed with pomp and pride
Title(s): ‘Remember man thow art but wormes mete’
Subjects: mortality; transitoriness, of life; sins, deadly
_description: ‘Remember man thow art but wormes mete’ — eight stanzas rhyme royal with refrain

BLAdd29729.First Lines:
O mortall man masyd with pompe and prideof vayne glorye makyng thyn
                    edifice…
BLAdd29729.Last Lines:
…If thow ax grace with contrite teres wetethy sowle may lyve
                    thowghe thow be wormes mete
BLAdd29729.Attributed Title:
Remembar man thow art but wormes mette (f. 7), by scribe (John
                    Stow).
BLAdd29729.Editions:
Edwards,  A. S. G. 
             “A Fifteenth-Century Didactic Poem in British Museum Additional MS
                29729.” 
             Neuphilologische Mitteilungen
         70 (1969): 702-06: 702.

BLAdd21410.First Lines:
o mortall mon with [þi senchis?] abusedgrasping after hie
                    prosperite…
BLAdd21410.Last Lines:
…and thow be riche more good woldyst thow geteremember mon
                    that thow art wormes mete
BLAdd21410.Note:
Fragment: stanza 1 only, added to margin by hand of sixteenth
                    century.
BLAdd21410.Editions:
Bergen,  Henry,
                        ed.  
             Lydgate’s Fall of Princes.
             4 vols. 
             EETS
         e.s. 121-24 (1924-27); repr. 1967: 4.65.

CantAdd46.First Lines:
O mortall man…syd with pom…Of veyne glory making
                    …thynne edylies…
CantAdd46.Last Lines:
…to theme that the wyll note sounter
                    ple…e……bre man thow art but w[or]mys mete
CantAdd46.Note:
The text survives on two damaged parchment fragments, resized on uniform
                    paper sheets.
CantAdd46.Editions:
Boffey,  Julia,  and  A. S. G. Edwards.  
             “Unrecorded Middle English Verse Texts in a Canterbury Cathedral Library
                Manuscript.” 
             Medium Ævum
         72 (2003): 49-62: 59.
